author: chrissorem
content: This made me think of a production technique Ive stumbled on.  We all have our go to instincts that can lead to a similar feeling across a  record.  Generally there is a dominant instrument that the song was written on such as guitar or piano maybe a synth.  Take a filled out productions and mute all the main ingredients and leave the additive colors, only the sprinkles on top. And start rebuilding the production around that. It can take you to an entirely different  universe and provide contrast in the arch of the record

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple things:
1) no one is actually a perfectionist. It doesn’t exist. I heard a great story of someone telling (I want to say) Richard Marx that he hadn’t released his record yet cause he’s a perfectionist and RM replied “Bullshit. Name one thing you’ve ever done that’s actually perfect. You’re just scared to move on.”  That story has stuck with me.

2) I’m a fairly decent guitar player, have made an actual career of being paid to do it. And I STILL am either constantly hiring people better than I or recording things note by note and then assembled in protools afterwards. Dr Luke might be the best guitarist I’ve ever been around (and I’ve hung with Blake Mills, Tim Pierce, Phil X), and he CONSTANTLY would just hit record, play the four chords of the song free time, and then cut them up and drop them on the ones or wherever they’re supposed to go in the song. My favorite thing about making records vs performing them live is that on record NO ONE CARES how you got there, just that you did. Unless your groove has something particularly magic to offer I’d get over the one take mentality pretty quick.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Someone in the mix channel had mused about what Serbian’s assistant’s do, and it brings me back to “The people that know how will always work for the people that know why”

Do you know the actual reasons why you feel your work doesn’t measure up yet? Hint: it’s very rarely strictly the sonics and/or mix. That Olivia Rodrigo album sounded objectively terrible, but FELT awesome. And that’s what mattered in the end.  Benny Blanco became successful with a folder full of songs at 120 bpm cause he didn’t know how to change the tempo, and stacks of kick drums because he didn’t know how to eq (he just layers a brighter kick on top if it needs more snap). When I’d ask him why he pretty much did anything it was always “I dunno, man, it just sounds cool!”. Make sure you’re attacking the work with that kind of mindset. 

When I get lost in the minutiae I try to zoom out and just be like “does this whole track feel good? Am I instinctually bobbing my head?” And if not, why?

95% of the songs that people have sent me here, the issue hasn’t been their space, or their monitoring, or whether they used a 60s or 70s guitar, or if they mixed analog or in the box. The issues almost always tend to be much less narrow in scope. Make sure you zoom out and just go “is this cool?”

author: BatMeckley
content:
I worked with a band at the very beginning that was a three piece with VERY specific rules. 

1) all songs had to be under 2:45
2) guitars and vocals could be doubled for tone, but not parts.
3) bassist sang lead, if there was a harmony the guitarist (not a gifted singer) had to sing it, if there was a third part the drummer had to sing it (couldn’t sing at all)
4) record couldn’t take more than a week to record/mix 

It was the project that convinced Luke I could be a producer; his fav record id done up to that point.

There’s a real value to putting strict limitations on your art, it often brings the most clarity and creativity. Side note: they were terrible technical musicians but just fucking AWESOME.

author: popaganda.
content: No matter what I’d be trying to build off a live performance. Vocals and guitar at the same time if possible, make sure the artist is comfortable enough to really deliver the way they did on their videos. Sometimes when artists get in the studio they get way in their heads, and then the process of doing takes and dressing up a track piece by piece can really cloud up the original energy that the fans connected with. So no matter how you eventually dress it up, the core has to be as dynamic and connective as possible.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Granted, her examples are *very* specific to orchestra and not directly applicable to pop records, but the underlying principles here include:

**1) **Think of instrument combinations as a single composite voice.

One instrument can function as the "sustain" portion of the sound and a second instrument gives the "attack". Together they create a single melodic voice.

**2) **How do the instruments stack on each other? Do they clash? Cellos doubling a bass an octave up extend it's timbre into a higher register to make it read better. It's not so different from adding fuzz to an 808 so that it has more presence.

**3) **Which instrument will cut through the music?

---

A few concepts that I'll add:

**4) **Instruments in the foreground vs. the background. Know which part is the lead (focal point) at any given point in the record and then pare down the presence of the rest and push it into the back of the sound stage.

**5)** (Piggybacking off of Felix's excellent post) What is the simplest way to achieve the desired effect? Reduce. Reduce. Reduce.

Cut instruments and parts ruthlessly and approach it with a minimalist's eye. Like writing a haiku: How few elements can you use to create an impression? Maybe a guitar part is carrying 90% of the groove and the drums only need to be a kick and a snare. Or maybe the guitar is covering the backbeat too, and you don't even need a snare!

Constantly ask yourself "What is the most important sensation in the record?" and then focus it by cutting out everything that gets in the way.

**6)** Hocketing. Pass the melody off between different instruments at different points in the song. Play it in different registers. Combine voices occasionally for special effect.

**7)** Tonal contrast. Dark instruments plus bright instruments. Distorted and clean together. Near vs. distant.

Elements that sound same-y will gel together and elements that contrast tonally will pop.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I couldn't speak to the current state of samplers, but I've always wished that someone would build a bold sampler that wasn't afraid to be really wacky and full of unique characteristics. For starters:

1. Include a radio tuner. 
2. Maybe some really nice - but heavily colored - preamps.
3. Include all kinds of weird peripheral sensors like devices that pick up EMF signals or a few contact mics. Include a suite of effect plugins that are specially geared towards these input methods.
4. Super-intuitive resampling, time-stretching, and pitch-shifting features.
5. An algorithm that analyzes the dominant pitch of a loop and auto-maps it to a keyboard. It should be capable of re-orienting itself as the dominant pitch of a loop is adjusted.
6. Tracker-style sequencing capabilities.
7. An OTT-style compressor. Maybe something really trashy and blown-out like Devil-Loc or Vulf Compressor. Something that really messes with the proportions of a sample.
8. Easy and flexible integration of feedback loops.
9. Intuitive integration of polyrhythmic looping or sequencing.
10. A feature for easy implementation of Steve Reich 'It's Gonna Rain' style tape loop phasing.
11. Auto-bpm detection keyed off of designated inputs (ala Ableton).
12. Automated master tempo effects.

I could go on.

author: popaganda.
content: I’ll add kind of a different angle to this convo….everything mentioned is crucial…play a lot, record, play with others, just reps….but if you want to see big gains TECHNICALLY on something like guitar or piano, you need to break movements down and very very slowly drill the transitions….one note to the next. One chord to the next…really building muscle memory. For a new chord shape…form it very slowly and then let go completely. Repeat many times. Same thing for chord transitions….super slowly between the two. It may seem like it would take too long to practice like that, but doing micro work like that will completely transform your ability on an instrument if you’re judicious and persistent.

author: LAPhill
content: The hard truth is that, if you're going to be a producer recording your own parts, then it's your responsibility to figure out how to make them bang. And learning how to quickly and efficiently work around your limitations is part of the gig. Get really good at knowing where you can punch to hide the seams of comping, regardless of the type of part. Retune the guitar to make chord shapes easier. Split up the part. If you practice THOSE editing skills, your workflow will speed up tremendously. There's no need to concern yourself with being able to play it in one go, or at all, unless you're going to perform it live.

author: Slow Hand
content:
At the risk of stating the obvious, transitions can also be telegraphed through the instrumental writing too. Whether it's a drum fill, or a chord voicing that walks up/down into the next section, or tension in the melodic voices, or shortening the notes lengths (staccato, staccatissimo).

There's also idiomatic noises from the instruments. Guitars have string scrapes, headstock rakes, that cool chattering thing from tapping near the bridge with the edge of your pick. Pianos have big glisses, horns can squeal, bowed strings can sweep a fast legato scale up into the downbeat or do a large gliss.

Then there's foley. I get a *lot* of mileage from sound libraries made for film audio. Foley artists are some creative people and you can go far layering their sounds into instruments at the transitions.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
The method that sounds most transparent is hand editing (no digital stretching at all). You need to line up your edits so the wave form is perfect in the middle of each note, then use an equal gain cross fade at the edit point. This gives you the most transparency because there is no algorithmic stretching happening. 

It limits very slightly your options with timing because bass wave forms are long, so lining them up perfectly means you can only move the timing the length of each waveform. It's also time consuming compared to stretching.

If you are editing a DI that is then going through significant processing (amp sims and shit), you can sometimes get away with one of the stretching algorithms. Elastic audio is ok and usable sometimes, but I prefer Ableton's complex mode over everything else I've heard.

I try to avoid time stretching artifacts on lead vocals and bass instruments more than anything else (unless it's creatively interesting of course).

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Wanted to share some thoughts spurred on by a recent experience on here. So a local artist has hired me to produce two of her songs. Vibe is singer-songwriter, soul, RnB.

We tracked drums, bass, and keys live in the studio OD'd to scratch tracks we cooked up together. The scratch tracks / demos were just guitar vocal and we were really relying on the players to fill out the arrangements, but we knew more would be added down the line.

All the players were incredible. Could singe your eyebrows off with technical prowess and shredtastic chops. Tracks turned out great, still working on the arrangement, but..

This project has got me thinking more about the importance of how you present a song to session musicians and the 'space' you ask them to fill in a production. As well as the changing dynamics project to project affected by a revolving cast of participants, more fleshed out demos, etc... I find this a really interesting topic. Curious if anyone in the group has any unique experiences or insights whether as a producer or a musician.

I've found that the more I flesh out demos with the artist beforehand the more bound and limited the session players we bring in are based off our decisions. This can make ODs more efficient, add a clearer direction, but can also remove the opportunity for the player to really add something special. Sometimes I don't want to be too suggestive b/c I want the players to have more of a blank canvas to work with.

The law says "any use" needs to be cleared. One of the major legal cases even specified no minimum length.

That being said, nearly all drum one shots are commonly uncleared. There are some other exceptions that would fall under being a generic sound of some sort.

The short answer is, if someone can recognize it from their original recording, you can be sued. 

Most people don't bother trying to clear things because they don't have budget. Usually nothing ever happens because most songs don't get big enough for the copyright owner to care. Then again, I heard Gotye had to give away 80% of Somebody That I Used To Know because of the two chord uncleared bossa nova guitar lick.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Good question! 

As @cian riordan said, when you're perfectly lining up the waveform of any solid tone, you want equal gain so it doesn't give you a boost on the crossfade. This is for "correlated" signals where the waveform is lining up exactly. A bass guitar, the middle of a vocal note, a synth with a consistent waveform, etc.

When you're doing a crossfade on noise (breaths, sss's, ambience between drum hits, etc), you want equal power because these "uncorrelated" signals need a bit of boost around the crossfade for the perceived loudness to be the same.

You can check this by using a synth note or long vocal note, doing an edit to make it longer or shorter, lining up the waveforms perfectly, and doing a cross fade. You will find that equal power causes a volume bump. Equal gain will be smooth.

Do the same thing with white noise and this time equal power will be smooth, while equal gain will cause a volume dip.

author: peterlabberton
content:
I’m a drummer first, but now play bass/guitar/some minimal keys on a good amount of stuff I produce. Taking drums out of the equation (that was years and years of many many hours every day), I’ve just gradually improved on the other instruments to a point where I now feel comfortable playing on a record. There have been moments of sustained growth in a given instrument, but really it’s just been time and growing as a *musician*—almost more a mindset of confidence. A baseline level of theory helps, then just a) learning songs, and b) learning how to play what you want to hear.

Also editing. Not gonna throw this person under the bus, but I got to work with a very A-list producer a couple years ago and recorded him playing drums (not his main instrument). Let’s just say it wasn’t great. But it got the idea down, and then edit edit edit. No shame, just make it great in the end!

author: BatMeckley
content: I was just bringing it up to be a schmuck and mildly difficult (largely because DP’s camp was pretty difficult with us when we’re on intersecting tours forever ago)  but it does bring up an important TOTALLY UNRELATED TO YOUR SPECIFIC DANIEL POWTER situation point: we’re in the business of tiny differences making huge differences. You can get a Warm 47 for a grand or real 47 for 15 grand and they’re preeeetttyy  close. But the devil is in the details. The original Dare you to Move (I think that song has had 4 different versions now) is pretty close to the Fields version… Fields rocked up the drums a little more, and by far most importantly  had my sage input (and gear) for a more kickass guitar sound. The song went from a heavily pushed song that couldn’t quite get its footing for them to a massive multi platinum career defining hit. It can be frustrating to watch someone else turn something we got 95% of the way there into the thing that got released, but often times it’s that exact skill which makes them worth the investment from the label. Understanding that difference and learning how to bridge the gap is the whole secret to making a living in this business.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I can't take credit for this framework (might have actually been in a conversations pod ep) but something I've adopted in my own production practice is the idea of convergence and divergence. If you are trying to converge on final guitar takes while your client is wanting to diverge and explore new creative ideas, then might be worth explicitly communicating 'this is where we're at and here's what we need to get done today' as lead producer before you begin tracking just so everyone knows. I'd be wary of stifling the exploration / play of your client, but maybe you could have them channel that into a notebook or voice memo in the back of the studio and you could schedule a time with the sole purpose of fucking around and exploring / playing with new ideas. Really just wanna make sure everyone knows when you're in 'convergence mode' and when you're in 'divergence mode' to avoid that frustration.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I really like the range function. There’s something in the way that it reacts that I just can’t get ProMB to sound the same. (And I’ve tried). 

I tend to be doing pretty wide, easy, just a few DB moves with it. The sharp resonant notches I used to use have been MOSTLY replaced by eq or soothe. 

You don’t have to use all the bands. Less is more. 

The whole reason I c6 over c4 is the side chain feature, where I’ll just have it last on say the guitar bus, triggered by the vocal, just ducking enough space to make the vocal a bit more intelligible. Bit like the song mixing itself. 
I find I’m not using c6 a ton on the actual track, it’s always side chained. 

C4 is more on the track itself. Really handy to focus a chunk of the audio. You can control the range of say 2-5k, and then move the entire volume of that up and down as it only dances with 5db of itself. Useful.

Not sure if I’ve mixed a song where the c4 isn’t on the drum bus somewhere.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another example:

On Brett’s last record, he did a demo with a co-writer of a song I loved. he tracked vocals with me, and I suggested the track needed a Mayer style guitar solo, so I played it. When Dann Huff heard it he told Brett “we’ll just upgrade Noah’s track to Master Scale. It’s not gonna get any better than that.”

When they went into the studio, they ended up taking the Mayer idea all the way, and the whole thing kinda went Country “Don’t Trust Myself.” They couldn’t do a Mayer solo on top of a Mayer vibe cause it would go from inspired by to straight derivative. 

My solo didn’t make the record, and I didn’t get any production credit. But the guy who did the demo did. I did get some BGVs on it and paid accordingly. All that felt right to me.

author: Zach Hughes
content: I also struggle to find a balance between focusing on production work and my songwriting. I was focused heavily on production work over the summer and then when my schedule loosened up in the Fall I started writing for my next album. I had done a little brainstorm session with chatGPT actually to help me create a daily schedule oriented solely around writing which was pretty helpful. But even when still in the production grind I like having guitars laying around so I can grab one when I take a break or bring on in the house with me. If you have the flexibility, w/o compromising deadlines, I've found it helpful to leave room to indulge the moments when songs / melodies / lyrics pop into my head even when my expectation that day was to work on a mix or other production. Be interrupted by the song and push everything else back an hour and see what happens.

author: Deleted User
content: Sooo, on the recording side of things: if you’re going DI, most interfaces do not have a high enough input impedance to do passive pickups justice, especially if you want a decent amount of low end. Guitar pickups sound good with 1-2MOhm(the input impedance of a good tube amp), but if I want really clear modern low end that can compete with 808s, then I’ve had the best results with around 10MOhm on passive bass pickups. Another important thing is a transistor-based active DI will not get you a full low end. You will end up re-amping or using amp emulations etc. Octal tubes(the type of tubes IN the B15) will. Octal tubes have a lot more body(think U47, for example) and will get you there much much quicker. I have a Sarno V8, which isn’t perfect, but sounds clean, “finished” and modern from the get-go. No compression or emulations needed. It’s also comparatively affordable, so totally worth every penny.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think the best thing you can do when learning a synthesizer is to pick just one or two and really take the time to learn them inside and out. There's so much overlap between the feature set and if you can get very intuitive with one synth you'll go so much farther.

Back in the day I bought NI's *Komplete* bundle and it was just way too many new instruments too fast. Too many options. I never got to know any of them very well. Most synths have all of the same features that you'll want, but there's still a learning curve for every single one that you have to get over before you can be really expressive. I wish it were as easy as picking up a guitar or a horn where everything is standardized and lies in the same place. But that's part of what makes synths great: Their plasticity.

Nowadays the only synths I reach for (unless I need a very specific sound) are *Massive X*, *Razor*, and my Moog Sub 37. The first two are very different and don't share many features. I use the Moog when I don't want to be tethered to my computer. Limiting my available tools has been a net benefit for me.

content: There’s two things going on here… one is the natural rub of harmonics that normally occur no matter the instrument, but there’s something specific that happens when you do chords like that pre-distortion, meaning the way an amp (or pedal) distorts that rub willl usually be different sounding than if you hit those notes on individual takes and THEN blended them together. I’d give that a shot (the aforementioned mutt lang one note at a time chord theory, which supposedly has been overblown, though I’ve heard guys like MUSE have explored it later on) before you go too haywire looking at dramatic eq moves or what not.

author: Slow Hand
content:
*Keyscape* has some fantastic sounding (and unorthodox) sampled keyboard instruments. That said I'm not particularly fond of the sound of it's LA Custom C7 grand piano. Which is a little too hi-fi for my taste.

Lately I've been very impressed by NI's/Kontakt's *The Maverick* grand piano. I believe it's a vintage Bechstein grand. The sound is robust and rich without all of the "zing" that I see in a lot of full-scale sampled grand pianos. It sounds "woody" to me. I think it would make for a very nice jazz piano.

They did a really good job of sampling every facet it and it has enough flexibility that you can dial in the really intimate Nils Frahm-style damper/pedal/mechanical noises, which I like.

inner harmonies are more textural than functional, they exist to fill the space in the middle, but they can also take up too much space. key players and guitarists are guilty of this too often. no need for a 7 note voicing in a dense pop song

But chord “progressions” are also underrated in a sense that it really shifts the emotional context. you can really make a pretty significant difference by carefully crafting them, but also that doesn’t mean you need all the stuff in between bass and the main melody on every songs

instruments like chord stabs can serve the function of percussion and drive the rhythm. it’s ‘rhythm sectio’  afterall

author: gatewoodsensei
content:
I’m not sure if this’ll help, but I tend to go with whatever hits me at the time. If it’s a melody, I’ll sing it, mumble words, and allow the music to form around that idea. If it’s lyrics, then i grab a guitar or sit in front of the keyboard and play the accompaniment. Or if I’m in front of my computer, and melody line hits, I’ll play the melody, or chords and allow it to loop while I write. So I don’t necessarily balance, because to me that means I’m shutting part of my creativity off i order to allow the other part to flow, and more often than not, that kills the creative flow. 

So don’t try to balance anything. Whatever you feel, go with that and allow your creativity to flow.

author: Adam Thein

This is probably repeat info but I like to split the audio between transients manually then use the Shift+Option+Command (on mac) combo and click drag the audio to slip the audio within the clip, then slice the next transient and you can get into a flow pretty fast and manually slice up an entire take pretty quickly.  Multimic sources like drums I do the same thing but with the "Link Tracks" option.  Can usually fly through a full song pretty quickly.

Especially for acoustic guitars, drums, and vocals that are super sensitive to warping this is usually my method in Ableton.

author: Deleted User
content:
Yeah. Also one other thing I’ve learned is that a guitarist could learn time on the picking hand but it can collapse once pick up another instrument. And that’s because time was only taught to the picking hand. Being able to internalize it through the whole body is my current goal. Bending legs or moving the whole body as opposed to just tapping one foot or moving my head back and forth. This may be a weird territory, but I feel the time from all the way down the navel when I feel locked in. But all of that can also collapse immediately once I start thinking about it. So visualizing clicks as my navel lighting up is something I am adding to my practice these days. 

I don’t really play drum sets but I’ll do a paradiddle every now and then to teach myself how to coordinate the timing between two arms

author: Deleted User
content:
Another thing that I found for myself - and this may not have anything to do with you

I spent a long time with my instruments (relative to my age and short years lived), but I didn’t spend a long time ON my instruments. Which led to self doubt on my chops. 

The self doubt was actually more detrimental to my timing than the lack of practice itself. But the self doubt was brought on because I didn’t spend enough time practicing my instrument and maintaining a healthy relationship with my fingers and the guitar. I’m still with a tons of self doubt but I am learning that as long as I’m working on the right things, practice won’t betray me. What I put in comes back out, and I had a weird relationship with that for a long time because I would work on a lot of wrong things and spend a long time doing that.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I asked a similar question a while ago, and @oaklandmatt had a great answer basically to the effect of: 
Something rushing ahead adds energy or anxiousness (a punk bass line or fast trap hihats, maybe a rock guitar solo)
Something late adds groove/swagger (Lofi hip hop snare, a lazy vocal, a funky bass line)
I think that’s a really cut and dry way to view it; but what you said obviously applies, every context is different.

author: cy (sigh)
content:
yeah its very case by case. as far as groove in relation to other elements. I've had guitars recorded loosely toa click and worked the groove around that - lining up the downbeats of the drums/bass  with the guitars even if it's a bit early or late. that was for a more indie type of joint. and for something more trap /modern hip hop, I've nudged bass notes or samples to get them to either sync w drums up for impact  or nudge slightly off to hype of of pull back the energy in the groove. 

as far as programming. I'll play with forward swing and dragging notes a lot if I'm going for a more real/dynamic feel when programming. keeping in mind that if the goal is trying to stay "on time" any fwd swing that might happen at the start of a phrase will be compensated with some drag  after or vice versa.  keeping velocities in mind w drum hits + linking it to a filter env so that harder hits have more high end and softer hits end up a bit rounder.

adding subtle layers that are similar   to the main drums but occupy a different texture or tone  in dif  sections to thicken up the groove or automate the attack /sustain of certain elements thru diff sections to help shift the listener  focus throughout

author: Rob Domos
content:
As a dude who's musical education was mostly in accapella music and who's production has mostly been midi that was easily quantizable, my sense of rhythm is nowhere near tight enough for the tier of work that I've been entering into lately. This means if I play something, I'm going to need to be quantizing audio and I'm relying on the visual aid of the waveform because my inherent sense of groove is pretty weak. So I'm looking for advice on quick heuristics for quantizing audio. 

Todays example: I played some palm muted acoustic guitars, I've marked the scrape of the pick in red and the peak of the waveform where the note truly starts ringing in green. The waveform actually starts a little before the scrape as you can see where the pick touches the string wave over on the left . How are y'all thinking about which part of this waveform should fall on which side of the beat?

author: Deleted User
content:
it’s generally the orange if it’s something like palm muted guitars. But always listen and feel it. It can feel better to be early in certain styles but it can feel better to be late on other styles. it also depends on who else is doing what

But groove template is always there if you wanna line it up with other instruments. bounce and make the source and destination audio files the same length, make sure the markers are in the correct place then sync them up. 

I’m 90% manual editing though. Because aligning automatically can fix notes I didn’t want to fix. you can also go measure by measure to be more careful if you want to auto align with groove templates 

you want to ask yourself “is this note late or early?” before making any moves. I like nudging with keyboard so I can fine tune how far it goes. 

Nowadays I’m more committed to “the only way to make the groove feel good is to play it that way”. I hate having to edit and to be honest, nothing beats well played rhythm section… Especially because I do a lot of in between the groove stuff, 30% quantization can mess with the feel of well landed notes. So I’m doing a lot of metronome practice these days

author: Deleted User
content:
re: 1 

I have gotten over the whole “perfectionism” thing. I still overthink all the time but I can confidently day I am free of perfectionism. I have no problem letting go when it calls for it. I believe there’s a difference between wanting to be better and working towards it vs not being able to move on out of fear and holding onto something without knowing the next move. If that was the case I wouldn’t have sent what I first recorded to the artist. I may have wasted some time thinking I would be able to get this part down, but I don’t think I was being a perfectionist by doing that. 

re: 2

Why would he do this if he’s a great guitarist? Is it a workflow preference or the aesthetic of edit/sampling? I can only imagine it being faster playing the parts in rather than stitching bits together. 



The whole goal is to be able to consistently reproduce that magical groove, and being able to create great moments when I am with other people. I really believe I have a good sense of groove but can’t execute it just yet. 

I can see myself spending countless hours editing myself. (Which I already do daily). That time is better spent working on my chops. If I can hire other musicians so I can stop wasting time trying multiple takes, I would. But I don’t have that just yet. I go by sections or measures most of the time, I don’t just sit there trying to nail ONE perfect take.

author: louisvie
content:
Hi everyone, here's the situation for me right now 

Singer/Artist/Band Leader wants to release big single with video in 4 days to coincide with band's concert. (In important small venue in Paris, FR (hometown) friends will be there, big event he rightly envisions as a celebration for the new kick-ass song with the new kick-ass video.)

But, as close friend, band-in-question-member, sound guy and producer for the project, I think we should wait and take time to get very good vocals, while right now it feels like they're merely existing because song has to have vocals. Leaves no strong impression, or the impression that the performance lacks intention.

Band rocks (his guitar included), Harmonies and Gang Vocals are cool. 
Really the lead vocal is the only thing in the way of getting the song to be really good. 

On the one hand, I feel like his intuition for the release date (deadline is in 4 days) is good and could be very valuable for us.
On the other, I don't see why anyone would be truly excited for us if singer is mid.
(I know he's good deep down, he's given me chills when singing with no pressure, rn we're just lacking some of that magic.)

As the song is today, you wouldn't love to listen to the song on your way to work or school, enjoying it for what it is.

Anyway, right now I'm going to try and squeeze that magic out of him in the next following days when we can see each other.
As I'm typing this I also realize I should send him the instrumental and let him try shit alone. 

Maybe that's my answer.

author: markmaclure
content:
Anyone have any tips on working with new artists/producers with no filter? Like where they NEED to try out every idea they have, even if it's not good, or if it's a bad time (ie we're tracking guitars and they stop everyone to try out a (bad) bass idea). 

I'm on a project right now where a new artist is bringing their songwriting partner to every session as a producer. This is their first production gig (which is fine), but we're wasting a lot of time on ideas that get scrapped later on. This person has a good ear, and occasionally has GREAT ideas, but it takes forever for them to let go of bad ideas. 

It takes all of my patience to very slowly walk them through why the ideas aren't working, and there's a lot of pushback when I do. A lot of "but can we just try it? I really feel like it will work" then 3 hours later "oh yeah I think you were right let's delete it".

author: Deleted User
content:
I want to chime in here, I mostly agree with what the others said and as long as you don’t unintentionally clip all is well. But I think we can dig a bit deeper.

I like to work in a way during tracking/production that’s maybe a bit more old school with shooting for around -18dbFS on the average. It gives me a kind of fixed reference in my mind which gives me enough headroom for most dynamics. Now the important part is you have to turn up your monitoring/headphones volume to be adequately loud to work with those lower levels and then leave it there.That being said it might be necessary to bring down other pre existing tracks that are too loud.

Now since the volume of the monitoring/headphones stays the same during that tracking session you can use the gain of your preamp (or the output gain of the compressor, if you’re using one on the way in) to adjust the vocal or instrument so that for every part of the arrangement it feels right. So in a sense you are pre mixing during the recording, taking off some work down the line

author: chris_donlin
content: Love this question, I’ve been on a big panning journey the last two months because I’ve always just doubled things and panned everything evenly. I was listening to an episode on Sonic Scoop about Nigel Godrich’s approach to mixing and it was really eye opening to hear how bold his mixes are. I used to get distracted when something was panned but not balanced but after just forcing myself to do it I’ve gotten more comfortable, and even fallen a bit in love with what panning can do. I’ve noticed I have a tendency to pan instruments a certain way, pianos sound better panned, electric guitars always feel better panned right, no reason why it just does. Find what feels good to you! I haven’t gotten bold enough to pan bass and drums to a side. One day

author: oaklandmatt
content:
And not just for making things incrementally better, but for solving problems as well.

I recently was mixing a song with a young mixer who I gave my session to. I heard a very subtle low and thump after two particular downbeat and we could not figure out what it was. We solo'ed some groups and then I remembered that he had replicated my autotune settings on the bass guitar (he had a slightly different version). I know from lots of tuning experience that different modes will occasionally cause different types of artifacts. So we solo'ed the bass, switched from "modern" (his default) to "classic" and it was solved.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Maybe it's just my taste, but if I'm sequencing sampled instruments I'm not trying to sample guitars and I don't think we need another drum library, either. Drums and percussion already translate well to sampling (for the most part). 

I want strings and woodwinds, or brass. Gimme some of that, and make it something with some real energy and excitement. Their platform seems capable of expressing things that traditional sampled instruments cannot do, so lean into those strengths and make the parts a little more opinionated. A little more unique.
